definition: The context defines ponds as **small (\<1000 m<sup>2</sup>), temporary, forested ponds**. It also distinguishes them from larger **lakes**.

The context states that **over 90% of all ponds and lakes are <0.01 km<sup>2</sup>**. It also distinguishes **very small ponds** as being **<0.001 km<sup>2</sup>** and notes they could number as high as 3.2 billion and cover 0.8 million km<sup>2</sup> of surface area. 

Additionally, the study specifically examines **very small (<0.001 km<sup>2</sup>), temporary ponds**.

The context defines ponds as **small (1 m² to ∼50,000 m²)**, **shallow**, **standing water bodies** that can either **permanently or temporarily collect freshwater**. 

It also states that ponds house a **richer tapestry of aquatic plant and macroinvertebrate species** than **larger water bodies (e.g., lakes and rivers)**.

Ponds are small standing waters varying in size from 1 m<sup>2</sup> to about 2-5 ha in area and may be permanent or seasonal, man-made or naturally created. 

While there is no universally accepted difference between a pond and a lake, most authors use a size-based classification with a boundary between 1 and 5 ha for practical purposes. Some studies restrict 'pond' to waters of no more than 0.5 ha, while others extend it to 8 ha in depth or 10 ha in area. The Ramsar Convention adopted a cut-off of 8 ha.
The context defines ponds as waterbodies **less than 1 acre** (Elton & Miller, 1954) and lakes as **less than 5-10 ha**.

The context defines **ponds** as: “small lentic ecosystems that permanently or temporarily hold water”. It further specifies that they are “shallow” and “their size ranges from a few square metres to several hectares”.

The context defines **lakes** as constituting “a small percentage of the total number of lakes” and states that studies have “concentrated mainly on moderately large lakes”.

The context states that the small water bodies sampled are referred to as ''ponds'', since most of them correspond to the criteria of the definition of a pond presented by Oertli et al. (2005a). However, the specific criteria of that definition are *not* provided in this excerpt.
